description:
One of the men who'll stand in February's election to replace Sepp Blatter as FIFA president says the law must take its own course in relation to the charges brought against Mr Blatter by FIFA's Ethics Committee. Currently suspended the FIFA president denies any wrongdoing and has his personal hearing with the ethics adjudicator this Thursday. Verdicts in his case and that UEFA president Michel Platini are expected before the end of next week. South Africa's Tokyo Sexwale hopes to be the next FIFA president, he's been speaking to HARDtalk. Here on the BBC.

"These are friends, I repeat. These are colleagues. We have been with them in World Cups and also are with them. However, if any of them once being friends, were doing nefarious things, the law must take its own course. Yes, we are prepared as leader of FIFA if I'm elected to make sure that on the basis of international best practice, transparency, good democracy, openness, financial accountability, those are the things that have caused the lack of them, they've caused the problem right now. So we are prepared to clean up, but I don't run away from people I know."
